review_title: Poor Culture and Highly Paid Exec
pros:
The students are inspiring and impressive. The mission to better the world through Sustainable Development Goals is notable.

The people I worked with were great.
cons:
Leadership is less than ideal. The top 5 or so positions at the organization have extremely high salaries while the rest of the staff is poorly compensated for their hard work, long hours, and difficult work environment at no fault of theirs. The organization has trouble maintaining and acquiring donors due to empty promises and unrealistic goals set. There is poor communication and lack of positive culture creating an atmosphere full of constant stress and frustration at situations that are avoidable. 

*Please note many of these reviews are from students and NOT actual Enactus employees. Make sure to filter through the reviews for feedback from paid staff members for accurate depictions.

job_title: Regional Program Manager in Springfield, MO
pros:
**NOTE** Many of the reviews on this page are for students who engage in membership/leadership in Enactus clubs on campus, not who work for Enactus/Enactus USA HQ.

+Our network of students and faculty is on-board and passionate about the mission to be part of a better, more sustainable world. They are often proactive about opportunities and develop projects that are innovative, sustainable, socially-minded, and/or entrepreneurial in nature.

+Other RPMs were very engaged in the mission and a pleasure to work with.
cons:
- Terrible leadership at the international and national levels impede organizational stability and growth

- For an org centered on innovation and good business principles, Enactus cannot effectively innovate or maintain a budget. Numerous layoffs have wreaked havoc on the staff's sense of security. 

-Innovations promoted by senior leaders are not sustained. As a staff member, any new projects/programs I had to implement changes in operations on my own with little internal buy in and little/no budget. If it went well, then it was claimed as an organizational success and replicated. If it did not have the intended impact, I was ostracized and humiliated. 

- Toxic work culture with little accountability and lots of office gossip. Perceived factions do little to unify the organization in the face of an uncertain future.

-CEO Rachael Jarosh does not know how to work with others and garner trust.

-Big disconnect between funding mechanisms and donor expectations, student/faculty expectations, and expectations of staff.

-HR does not function appropriately. Nothing can be said in confidence and processes are not followed to resolve issues - especially between staff and a senior leader.

-Very little racial diversity as part of Enactus international / Enactus USA.

pros: Coworkers are very supportive. The organization is a well-oiled machine in event management. The mission is unparalleled. Benefits are very good. There are lots of networking opportunities with partner companies when it's time to move on.
cons: In any non-profit, you expect to wear many hats, pitch in where possible, and to hit hard deadlines. Enactus does all of that and keeps to an exceptionally high standard as expected with Fortune 500 partners. There is little room to grow within the organization and each member carries a heavy workload. Most staff work through lunch breaks. Salaried employees will often work nights and weekends to ensure their goals are met. There are lingering communication issues between departments, but it's well known and a point of attempted improvement. As a result of all of these factors, there is a high turnover on staff every few years. It's a non-profit salary, headquartered in the Midwest. Compensation is low compared to level of responsibility.

review_title: Great Mission But Facing Some Challenges
pros: Casual work environment, flexible work hours, and options to work from home one day a week. Updated work space in a shared building with a cafeteria. Fairly good benefits considering it's a non-profit. Great mission that makes you feel good about what you are contributing to the world.
cons: Uncommunicative, rarely seen CEO. 90% of leadership works remote and are also rarely seen by the majority of the workforce which is located at HQ. Company struggles with financials which have declined over the years. Career growth is slim - it's a small company, not a lot of upward mobility. Company is top heavy - too many leadership roles and not enough staff in support roles (which often do the majority of the heavy lifting). Long term employees seem to be forgotten in lieu of newer staff.

pros: Fulfilling work seeing how communities are changed and impacted by the youth and the corporate social responsibilities of organizations. With very little resources, creative thinking and implementation of simple solutions to livelihood issues many lives were uplifted and improved.
cons: The work can lead to burn out. Working in non profits is not easy, there are many problems to be solved and in the midst of feeling as if you've made a significant difference to some, there are still so many more who need assistance. In a nutshell your job is never done.

review_title: A heart for the world and...?
pros: This organizations mission is externally magnificent. The opportunities, experiences, and life lessons gained by Enactus students is truly inspiring.
cons: The leadership has a lack of professionalism, follow through, and effective communication. There is an obvious disconnect between the CEO and all other leadership. There is a general lack of management and communication experience department wide. Their strategy and management style is often manic and chaotic. Lastly, management has a habit of forming focus/project groups meant to empower employees. Sadly these  groups become a source of busy work for employees and are rarely carried out by upper management.

review_title: Understand how a market based economic system operates.
pros: Participating students form teams on their university campuses and apply business concepts to develop outreach projects that improve the quality of life and standard of living for people in need.
cons: Acquire the education and skills training needed to succeed in a dynamic, competitive global economy.

review_title: Good people, good mission, but has some challenges ahead
pros:
First, to understand some of the challenges of being employed at SIFE, you must understand that SIFE is a non-profit organization that is funded through corporate donations.  This in itself causes budgetary guidelines to be off from what would generally considered acceptable for a department at other companies.

I have to say that during my tenure at SIFE I have been constantly impressed by how hard working, caring, and capable the people are around me.  I truly believe that the mission of the organization is important and on the right path.  Charismatic and passionate leadership at all levels of management help to drive the organization in a unified direction.

If you're interested in dealing with unique challenges, especially in creating innovative solutions on a shoestring budget, this could definitely be the place for you.  I've found it educational in my own way to work at SIFE.  Moving from the privately and publicly held enterprise to the non-profit sphere can be shocking and challenging, but it is well worth it to see the impact you make or you facilitate in making happen.

While the pay rate is below local market standards, the benefits package is second to none.  Management has a great respect for work/life balance and they are very easy-going about taking time off and working out making that time up so that an hour here or there doesn't eat into your paid time.  First rate medical and dental coverage, and good opportunities for retirement investing.
cons:
I don't think this is unique to SIFE, it's definitely a challenge at all non-profits, but the largest downside to being employed at SIFE is that your pay rate is not within the band usually considered appropriate for your job duties, responsibilities, and skill level in the local market.  Expect to make 50-70% of what is generally considered median pay for your job title and skill.

Additionally, while I feel that senior management is extremely passionate about what they do, and they have a clear and positive vision for the future, there is an inordinate amount of internal politics for an organization of this size.  At times, when trying to make anything from minor to major changes, it would be near impossible to move forward due to internal politics and bureaucracy.  I think much if this has to do with a conscious effort on the part of management to be judicious in their spending, but in many ways it can make the job more stressful and unsatisfying than necessary.

Overall I think SIFE is a good organization with a good mission, and that they are successful and will continue to be successful, but they definitely have some challenges ahead.  Most of the challenges I feel they've experienced have come down to funding and mismanagement of people resources.  We've got a very high turn-over rate in some job areas compared to other organizations of our size in the local market.

pros: Travel all over the US and to international locations, great mission, great people, glad to have a job during tough economic times, good for young singles
cons: Non-profit pay lower than private sector, career advancement difficult, constant travel makes it hard if you have a family, headquarters based in Springfield MO is not a great location to fly from, often had to drive to Kansas City to fly out because airfares were so prohibitive from Springfield
